Description.val: MARK (MK) XIIA Mode 5 provides improved secure cooperative combat identification via the Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) system.  Mode 5 compatibility is part of the Combat Identification (CID) Family of Systems (FOS) strategy employed by US and North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)/Allied forces and will improve situational awareness, reduce fratricide, reduce enemy disruption of IFF functions and ensure the safe return of friendly aircraft.  The DoD implementation is governed by AIMS 03-1000A and USN requirements defined in ORD # 577-06-01 and is designed to be compatible with civillian IFF modes to ensure interoperability of military and civilian aircraft. Mode 5 is a product improvement which is designed to be installed through engineering changes to digital MARK XII IFF Systems (interrogators and transponders) and their associated cryptographic material.

Justification.val: Joint Requirements Oversight Council Memorandums (047-07 and 122-08) endorsed a Mode 5 Joint Initial Operational Capability (JIOC) in FY14 and Joint Full Operational Capability (JFOC) in 2020.  NSA declared IFF Mode 4 unsecure and obsolete on 5 Nov 2003. Mode 5 provides added security and more data transmissions than Mode 4. Additionally, Mode 5 will use a spread spectrum waveform, which reduces susceptibility to interference.

Name.@footnote: Data Costs are estimated based on platform requirements and phasing and increase as more platforms execute Mode 5 upgrades in a given year.

Training costs are estimated based on platform requirements, e.g. operational and/or maintenance, and phased according to the platform schedule.  For example, FY17 includes both operational and maintenance trainer upgrades for incorporation of the AN/APX-123 in AV-8B.
Other Support costs are estimated based on the platform requirements and phasing and increase as more platforms execute Mode 5 upgrades in a given year.

A-Kit Recurring unit prices vary from platform-to-platform based on the complexity of the implementation required to achieve the Mode 5 capability. Mode 5 IFF A-Kits will be required for installation on the AV-8B, C-130T, C-20, C-37, C-40, CH-53E, E-6B, F/A-18C/D, KC-130T, MH-53E, and UC-35 platforms along with the "B" kits. A-Kit applicability and phasing changes are due to refinement in platform requirements and complexity of integration.  Many other platforms will only require "B" kits (e.g. Mode 5 upgrade of AN/APX-118 to AN/APX-123 is a form, fit replacement in the aircraft).  Installation costs vary by platform based on the implementation required to achieve the Mode 5 capability.

B-Kit Recurring unit cost varies based on what equipment is procured in each year.  Installation costs vary by platform based on the implementation required to achieve the Mode 5 capability.  The B-Kit solution varies (box or modification kit) from platform-to-platform based on the implementation required to achieve the Mode 5 capability, resulting in an AN/APX-123, AN/APX-111, or AN/APX-119.  AN/APX-123 boxes/kits have been procured and will continue throughout the program.  AN/APX-111 box/kit procurements start in FY13.  Procurement of the F/A-18 AN/APX-111 Receiver-Transmitter (R/T) Shop Replaceable Assembly (SRA), due to Mode 5 transponder performance issues, is now included in the Mode 5 kit procurement.  AN/APX-119 box/kit procurements start in FY15.  B-kit total quantity has decreased as platform requirements have changed.  In addition to providing Mode 5, the systems will provide Mode S capability.  PMA213 works closely with PMA209, who provides Mode S capability for platforms.  To achieve full fielding of both the Mode 5 and Mode S capabilities, both PMA213 and PMA209 BLIs integrate and install end items that are required to meet the full platform installation requirements.

B-Kit Non-Recurring increases in FY15 and FY16 to support aircraft ECPs on additional platforms. Specifically, funding has been included to address Mode 5 transponder performance issues with the F/A-18 AN/APX-111 Receiver-Transponder (R/T) Shop Replacement Assembly (SRA).  B-kit NRE is for this effort is required for full Mode 5 transponder functionality and intra-service interoperability.  In addition, KC-130T, AV-8B, and commercial derivative aircraft commence in those years. Some platform ECPs are more complex than others so the B-Kit Non-Recurring is based on the specific platform implementation.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Field Installs kits and Vendor Depot ECP Install : Installation Name: Mark XIIA Mode 5 IFF

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  MK XIIA Mode 5 provides improved secure cooperative combat identification via Identification Friend or Foe (IFF). Mode 5 compatibility is part of the Combat Identification (CID) Family of Systems (FOS) strategy employed by US and North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)/Allied forces and will improve situational awareness, reduce fratricide, reduce enemy disruption of IFF functions and ensure the safe return of friendly aircraft.  The DoD implementation is governed by AIMS 03-1000A and USN requirements defined in ORD # 577-06-01 and is designed ot be compatible with civillian IFF modes to ensure interoperability of military and civilian aircraft. Mode 5 upgrades existing Mode 4 IFF equipment, including cryptography, support equipment, and associated hardware and software changes. Mode 5 is designed to be installed through engineering changes to digital MARK XII interrogators and transponders and their associated cryptographic material including, but not limited to the AN/APX-118/123, AN/UPX-37/41C, AN/APX-111, and AN/APX-119. Joint Requirements Oversight Council Memorandums (047-07 and 122-08) endorsed a Mode 5 Joint Initial Operational Capability (JIOC) in FY14 and Joint Full Operational Capability (JFOC) in 2020. Mode 5 will be installed in Navy/Marine Corp/Coast Guard Type/Model/Series aircraft which are currently Mode 4 IFF capable with retrofit phasing to support JIOC and JFOC.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  MODE 5 completed a brassboard development in December 1997. Modeling and simulation to demonstrate interoperability was completed in February 1998 to support NATO STANAG development. Proof of concept flight testing completed in December 1999. Milestone B was completed in March 2003. Milestone C and Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) was approved in July 2006. Full Rate Production (FRP) was approved July 2012. FRP procurements and Mode 5 Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) on Navy/Marine Corp aircraft continue as the program continues towards JIOC in FY14 and JFOC in 2020.
